page.title: 06TEKELS PARK cont.
page.content: and plants, and the park is noted for its natural history; foxes and badgers are common, there are many bats and sparrow hawks and nightjars that occasionally nest in the park. Most of the houses on the site are the property of the Theosophical Society, though a few are privately owned. Most were built in the 19th Century, and are built in the same style as the old castle. When the motorway was built across the old park, the large lake in the park had to be drained. This played havoc with the water table and many houses in the area suffer now from subsidence. Gossip has it that the estate was bought by John Tekel after it had been lost at a game of cards attended by the future George 1V.Part was then sold to primeminister Pitt for RMCS.
